My maternal Grandfather game me a game like this when I was a kid, but the molded plastic has broken numerous times. I have no idea what this game is called. I made use of tbuser's 8bit font (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2054) for the numbers on the dice. I made no attempt to balance the dice as I do not throw them.

I printed this in white with 3 extra layers and no infill. After printing, I colored all six faces of the center die and one of the exterior die with a wide tipped black Sharpie leaving the numbers white. The other five dice I filled in the number with a fine point black Sharpie. Modifying this for multiple colors is left as an exercise for those with multiple extruders. ;-) By happy coincidence the maximum dimension is ~98mm so it should fit on Makerbots or larger platforms, (thing-o-matics may need to rotate by 30Âº?). Either way, the scad is included so feel free to modify if necessary. The game is played by randomizing the dice (I usually just roll the whole thing around in my hand or up and down my arm) and then placing on a flat surface. The values of the two black die are added to determine the target value. You must then use the values of each of the 5 white dice exactly once along with any mathematical operations you want to reach the target value. There are usually multiple solutions, but I believe some combinations are impossible. You can add any other house rules you want to increase/decrease the challenge (must use dice in clockwise direction, time limits, head to head, can/can't use lesser known operations like modulo, etc.) E.g. For the numbers in the picture the target is 40 + 2 = 42.
One possible counter/anti clockwise solution is: (2 + 3) (6 + 3) - 3 = 42.
Another is: 2 ^ 3 6 - 3 - 3 = 42.
Moving clockwise: ((3 / 3) + 6) 3 2 = 42.
In no particular order: 6 (3 + 3) + (2 3) = 42. Yes, many of the above parenthesis are extraneous and yes, I always consider the number a 6 even if it looks like a 9. Sorry about the large filesize. What's the easiest (preferable open source or at least free) software to reduce stl filesize?

This thing removes the constraint on the top of the threaded rod on a Hictop Prusa i3. The reason for this is to keep the wobble towards the top of the rod away from the x axis carriage. This is a much better solution than putting a bearing at the top of the threaded rod further constraining it and forcing the wobble towards the carriage thus causing striations in the print. The printed part on the left was printed after the installation of the rod delete and the part on the right was with the stock setup. The exact same layer height and all print settings were used and no other adjustments of any kind were made to the printer so the proof is in the pudding. The part is designed to fit a little tight but no filing is necessary. Simply take off the acrylic piece on the printer and bolt this one on. One could take the smooth rod off of the printer and place the thing on a flat surface and gently tap the smooth rod through the thing  if necessary. Just make sure you don't bend the smooth rod.

I designed this in blender as an orthocopter stlye drive mechanism for a butterfly project i am working on.
A linear movement on the "Ball" string causes mirrored rotational movement on connected arms.

Print 2 Cogs,2 arms,2 pins
1 support bracket
0.1mm or better layer height (thats is if you want small mech.) The Ball chain shown needs support to baseplate whilst printing .... NB:- Make sure the first layer is a good one (or a ball may shoot of the print table....trust me on this one) Press fit the pieces together (they are designed as interference fit)
Work the peices back and forth until they glide... it takes a while .. this will result in a gear system with less back-lash.

description.text:
I was inspired by Adafruit's DIY Bluetooth Gamepad, but did all the work for the models myself.

Additionally to the features Adafruit's game pad of roughly the same size, this one features L/R shoulder buttons and curved top and bottom edges, so it will lay in your hands really smooth.

• Adafruit Bluefruit EZ-Key Bluetooth HID module
  • LiPo Charger (I used this one, but you can use any you can get in your area that has appropriate voltage and amperage for charging you battery, you may have to customize the BottomShell.stl in that case, though)
  • LiPo battery (again, I used this one, but you can use any that fits the case, potentially redesigning part of its inner structure will be needed)
  • 10 tactile switches (6x6x5 mm)
  • 1 on/off switch
  • wire
  • prototyping board/etched PCB
  • of course access to a 3D Printer and filament unless you want to order the parts at some sort of service
  • soldering iron

• You will need a prototyping board to mount the buttons to, positions for buttons and holes can be taken from the top shell (I may add a layout later, though).
  • All the electronic parts are fixed to the lower part of the case.
    • Be sure to mount the EZ-Key upside down, so the reset key is reachable through the reset hole in the bottom of the case using a needle.
    • The charger goes to the central hole in the L/R buttons' side of the case, mount the on/off switch next to it
    • The battery snaps right into place if you have the same one as I do.
    • After that solder wires to EZ-Key pins 0-9 and one of the Gnds.
    • Solder the wires to the buttons contacts and fit the button boards in their places.
  • Maybe you have to file the buttons or holes a little so they can move freely. Last thing to do is fit the buttons into their holes in the upper part of the case and put it all together. If you're lucky you may not even need to glue the case halves together.

Notes: I had a problem with low printing speeds (20 mm/s), but that could be just my printer, where it would print shifted by about 2 mm from a layer somewhere amid the print and up to the last layer.
Printing was fine at 40 mm/s, though. However, Slic3r seems to have an issue slicing BottomShell.stl, I used Cura for that part, but printed the rest using Slic3r and Pronterface again.
I used a raft for BottomShell and did get worse results than for the TopShell, where I used none. I however recommend using a skirt at least. Supports don't seem to be needed.

Maybe you'll want to smoothen the edges and get rid of the printing pattern on planes using some sandpaper, however that's not required.
Make sure to clean your print of any excess material especially around the buttons' places, so they can move freely.

Seattle Sports made a snowshoe before discontinuing it; they sold their stock to Amazon who sold them for under $50.  And for good reason; the bindings break when they get cold - not great for a snowshoe.  Replacements cost as much as the snowshoe, so I thought I'd create a reinforcement to minimize breaking (I also used to to rejoin a binding that completely broke in half).
I used #10-32 x 5/8" zinc bolts with large washers on the top and smaller ones on the bottom with Thread Lock Red to prevent the nuts from coming off.
I did both feet to keep the height the same.
UPDATE: The PLA didn't last very long, so I reprinted using 3DXTECH PETG + Carbon Fiber.

Custom ski pole handle. I think it's not the best idea to 3D print the handle directly; I made a mold and used Modelite - it can be a bit brittle, but if you get the pole along the entire length, it's strong enough. You could also use something like Silicone. You can customize the Inventor mold file, but it's easier to update the pole adapter. I've included a customizer. Just set the diameter to your pole size (in mm) - the adapter then fits in the mold - it also adds support to keep the pole level in the mold while the handle material hardens. The handle goes with the basket to make a complete pole using any pole material you have on hand. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1296332

Printer:

QU-BD Two Up

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

30%

Notes: The mold does not need to be particularly strong; I printed in PLA with a low infill. I used CuraEngine with no additional Adhesion. No support is necessary for the mold pieces if you orient so that the pegs are up; printing the handle directly would require all sorts of support - Resin printer might be better for that.

This is my first version of a R/C steerable bristlebot. I was inspired by the Evil Mad Scientist Labs' design(http://www.evilmadscientist.com/article.php/bristlebot), but I wanted to make a cheap, vector-steerable bristlebot, and this is what I came up with. Powered by two vibrating motors and two toothbrush heads (read the EMSL post to see more about what types of toothbrushes work), this little bot scoots around the floor at delightful speeds. It's like the scrubbing bubbles mascot and a hummingbird had a kid. Video of an early prototype doin' its thang is here: http://www.flickr.com/photos/bridgewalker/6276616359/in/photostream

I chopped the heads off a couple of toothbrushes and glued them to the bottom of the platform.  It doesn't really matter what type or brand of toothbrush you get, as long as the bristles are angled in one direction.  It's got to act like a bristly little ratchet.
I used whatever vibrating motors I had on hand which happened to be 3V, .5" diameter, .75" long motors, but I've put in a handful of different motors, and the basic concept still works.  If the motors are too powerful, the vibrations from one side will drive the brush on the other side, as well, and it'll reduce the 'bot's ability to steer.  I hold the motors and electronics in place with a dab of hot glue.
For a controller, you can use any R/C controller that's capable of driving two motors.  I ripped the guts out of a Deskpet Skitterbot to get a cute little I/R controller with buttons that let me drive the 'bot forward and turn it around, and also have an integrated 70mAh LiPo battery that ran the 'bot for about 10 minutes between charges.  You don't need to be able to reverse the motors--vibrations in one direction are as good as vibes in another.  I'm sure you could do awesome stuff with an arduino or other micro telling it how to move.  Just dial the speed wayyy down, because it's pretty chaotic when the motors are at full power

description.text:
Keeping your pens and pencils organized is important for all artist work spaces. This desk toy design was inspired by Andy Warlhol's famous fashion sense and will keep your pencils all lined up for you. The project was an exploration into desktop 3D printer constraints. The desire and feasibility to combine multiple colours outputs into a single object using a consumer grade printer. The end result was a practical yet fun looking desk toy that can be printing on almost any common 3D printer. Multiple iterations where quickly designed and tested using Fusion 360. The final model was printed on a common 3D printer using two different PLA plastics at 300 microns. TO DO

If you don't make them in black you probably need to coat the inside with paint or the picture is tinted by the plastic color. My picture became very blue before I coated the inside.

author: rrobot1234

title: Project Shellter - Proof of Concept Shell

description.text: Dyn-o-Mite! err... I mean Amm-o-nite! This proof-of-concept is modeled on the shell of an Ammonite, a prehistoric ancestor of cuttlefish and octopi http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ammonite. This is the first shell from which a printable STL was created, and its creation spurred the continued development of Project Shellter. It was created using the Maya shellNode plugin and thickened using 3DS Max (still looking for an open source thickening solution!). Not-so-Good News: the shellNode plugin is only available as C++ source code in the Maya SDK. Good News: AutoDesk, the developer of Maya and 3DS Max, is helping out the 99% with their Educational and Professionals Assistance program. If you're a student, teacher, veteran, or unemployed individual who has previously worked in the architecture, engineering, design or manufacturing industries you can get AutoDesk software through their assistance program: http://students.autodesk.com/?nd=register

This was printed on a Thing-O-Matic with a Mk 7 extruder at the world famous BotFarm using Matt's excellent support settings: http://www.makerbot.com/blog/2011/06/27/makerbot-microtip-using-the-support-features-in-skeinforges-raft-tool/ Some notes:
  • It is oriented to minimize interior support; re-orient at your own risk ;)
  • You only need the STL or the zip file; they contain the same goodness!
  • Once printed, the minimal support material is easily removed and the entire shell is hollow
  • Sanding or tumbling to smooth the surfaces is optional but recommended (more on this later...)
    • While not too many hermit crabs will make a home in this, it's still a great horn for a mutant unicorn Halloween costume. Or print two for a mutant Thark or Warhoon costume! You can print it, I know you can! Go!

title: Prusa i3 Y Axis Bearing Rod Support

description.text: This is a replacement Y Axis Bearing Rod support for Prusa i3 Aluminum extrusion printers. It improves over stock versions by having a ridge that tightly aligns with the aluminum extrusion and having a bearing rod clamping feature.  There are right and left versions because the supports need to be mirrored to clear the bed adjusting screws. It requires two 5mm x 10mm cap screws for mounting and one 3mm x 12mm cap screw and nut for the clamp. You'll also need the captive nut used with the extrusion which came with the printer kit.

title: Power Planetary Reductor with Metal Part for Nema 17 motor

description.text:
Hello everybody! This is a reduce system with 4.5:1. It have metal part and work in the metall mill.
Ball screw is 1605 and 42byghw609 up to 4.0 KgCm motor. This mechanism multiplies the power of motor in 4.5 ones and do power on shaft about 18.0 KgCm or more for over motor in nema 17 series. If you need low speed CNC motion, you can do this reductor. For 1605 ball screw I have 180 motor`s steps per mm.
If you put 42byghw611 Nema motor you can have 4.8 KgCm * 4.5 = 21,6 KgCm on output staft. The sun gear teeth is 8.
Satellite gear teeth is 10.
Gear printed ABS plastic. Reductor used 2 ball bearing 607. Both bearing press in the mount and put down on the output staft. All gears-wheels place on mount with the small metal cylinder. Cylinder size: 4 mm radius, inner screw m4 and height 6-6.5 mm. You need processing 3 cylinder. Cylinder input in the satellite gear and screwed in mount. See the photo. The staft you need processing on the lathe. You can do cylinder 7 mm diametеr and long about 35 mm. After then you welding or soldering staft on the metal sheet 2 mm and cutting ring 22-23 mm radius. After then you drill 6 holes 4 mm diameter on the 19.5 mm radius from staft. This is ring you putdown to the screw on the plastic mount. After then you have metal staft on the mount like on the photo. Thank you for looking.
I wish you happiness and more lucky design.

title: Customizable Spring Footings for Replicator 2/2X Build Plate

description.text: After upgrading the extruder, adding a hood and side panels, adding a glass build plate, adding aluminium arms, and firming up the build plate pads, my Replicator 2 was still prone to occasional registration errors (misaligned edges) during filament changes mid print. I tracked down the problem to the lack of spring footings. This simple upgrade fixes this problem. UPDATE (Nov 14, 2013) Now customizable!
Print three, unscrew the Replicator 2/2X build plate, install under each spring and re-install build plate and re-level.

This is a right-handed stick for use in the sport underwaterhockey. UWH is played on the bottom of a swimming pool with scuba-gear, a cap, glove and a stick like this one. You can read more about the sport here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Underwater_hockey
For promotional goals I created this simplified stick to be printed at 20% scale to hand out to children.
The first picture features a full size XT-CF20 print, a bronzeFill and brassFill mid-sized print and a smaller woodFill print.
Check out my article on 3Dhubs for the bronze print as well: https://www.3dhubs.com/talk/thread/bronzefill-patina-processing
The other pictures are taken of these 20% scaled prints. You can also print them together with the puck: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:129668 -- Update 20-02-2014 --
I've added a holed version, designed for use as a keychain. Again, re-scale to 20% for a nice size. -- Update 16-05-2015 --
Another update, adding uwh-stick2.stl which has a curve on the bottom of the handle as well. This will need some support to print properly. Also added another picture.

• Download.
  • Slice (I used both Slic3r and Cura), a little infill (20%) and layerheight depending on the quality you want.
  • Print.
  • Post-process if you want.
  • Enjoy!
    • The bronzeFill print has been post-processed using a mixture of salt, vinegar and ammonia. For more info see the 3Dhubs talk: https://www.3dhubs.com/talk/thread/bronzefill-patina-processing.

title: High Quality Bearing Holder for Taz4 - 5

description.text:
I was replacing the plastic linear bushings with ball bearing bushings. Some of the bearing holders cracked under pressure from over tightening the screws. I've decided to design new bearing holders for the printer bed. The initial design incorporated wire ties. For the final design, I've decided to use heavy duty stainless steal 5/16" wide hose clamps. The result is a quality bearing holder. This holder will fit the LM10UU linear bearing. Edit 01/27/2016
The mounting holes measured from the center of the hole is 32 mm x 25 mm apart. The holes are fitted with M3 brass inserts. Edit 02/12/2016
bearing holder V4.stl is designed to hold the bearing in the middle allowing the bearing to pivot which will correct minor misalignment caused by the bed mount plate. The ability to pivot combined with adjustable tension on the bearing holder will eliminate binding of the X axis and off round issue with prints. Design Elements:
  • Easily swap bearings
  • Adjustable tension
  • Pivot
  • Low profile to allow equal or more printing height.

You can find the brass insert that I've used for this project at www.mcmaster.com I used the M3-.5 internal thread, 3.8mm length brass insert. The part number is 94180A331. To install the insert, you will need a tweezer, Popsicle stick or similar, and a fine tip soldering iron.
1) Heat up the iron to about 350 degrees Celsius.
2) Face the iron on an upward position.
3) Use the tweezer to place the brass insert onto the soldering iron. The narrow side of the insert should be facing upward. Note: From step 4 to step 6 should take no more than 10 seconds. Any more time than that the plastic will melt and deform.
4) Wait for 5 seconds and position the bearing holder towards the brass insert.
5) Push the insert into the bearing holder with gentle persuasion until only a little of the brass insert is protruding from the bearing holder.
6) Pull the soldering iron away and place it on a secure location. 7)While the plastic is still malleable, use the Popsicle stick to push the rest of the brass insert level with the bearing holder underside.
8) repeat steps 2 to 7 until all the brass inserts are in place. I personally like the inserts to be seated in more so I use the round edge or the Popsicle stick to push it further into the bearing holder.

comments.text: M3 inserts, how to mount, where to buy?

description.text:
This is a simplified puck for use in the sport underwaterhockey. UWH is played on the bottom of a swimming pool with scuba-gear, a cap, glove, stick and a puck like this one. You can read more about it here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Underwater_hockey
For promotional goals I created this simplified puck to be printed at 20% scale.
These will be handed out to children together with sticks: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:129665.
The pictures are taken of these 20% scaled prints.

• Download.
  • Slice (I used slic3r 0.9.10b) with 0.3 honeycomb infill. 0,2 layer height on a 0,35 nozzle. 20% scale (then they're just over 16mm in diameter).
  • Print.
  • Enjoy!

A scale-model of Canberra's iconic Telstra Tower on Black Mountain.
Cut in half vertically for easier printing. To make a complete model, print twice and stick the two halves together.
This model is probably too long and thin to print successfully. I will adapt my design to make the tower more squat (and less accurate).
This model was manually converted from a SketchUp model by Dark Cypher. I measured the model dimensions in SketchUp, and reproduced them in OpenSCAD.

Thanks to MustangDave and the original creator of this 3d photo scan, Fredrik Simons. Cut into parts using NetFabb, leveled using 3D Builder, sliced in MakerWare and printed in PLA (5% fill, 3 shells, no support) on a Replicator 2. When assembled, the three-part model stands about 14 inches high. Painted with acrylics. 2017-1-1 Update: A pre-hollowed version with 1mm walls prints well (and, being hollow, relatively quickly!) on M3D, Tiko, MP Select Mini, and other small printers. No support is needed.

comments.text: I printed the head piece with 0% infill successfully. The flat pieces of the two lower parts will tend to fail at 2x size without some sort of fill to support them. There's too much distance to bridge, most likely. If you do try it, skip the top fill and increase the # of shells to at least 4.

Chinese New Year Decorative Pieces
福 (pronounced as FU) means "fortune" or "good luck".
春 (pronounced CHUN) is a word associated with Spring.
大吉 (pronounced as DA JI) is typically written as 大吉大利 (Da Ji Da Li) meaning “Good luck and smooth sailing” These auspicious Chinese characters are typically used on decorative ornaments during Chinese New Year (CNY). My colleague designed these things to be 3D printed as decorative ornaments for one of my workshop on CNY lantern making. Enjoy printing and using them for your home decor as well.

remixed_from.title: Flashforge Creator Pro Adjustable Glass Bed Bracket

title: Flashforge Creator Pro Glass Adjustable Bed Bracket (MOD)

description.text:
A revised version of chewbone's Flashforge Creator Pro adjustable Glass Bed Bracket. Changes to corner piece:
  • This now has the screw slot the entire length of the corner so you can remove and swap these in without having to remove the pin completely.
  • The corner piece is taller, with 9.5mm clearance for the bed + blue sheet if you still have it on.
  • There is a lip that sits out 3.2mm over the bed to allow for glass plates up to 6mm smaller than the bed.
    • Additions:
    Added a blank corner piece with no lip to be screwed directly in place - aimed at back corners where adjustment may not be wanted.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm or smaller

Infill:

30% or higher

Notes: Print these in ABS as they will be subjected to high temperatures when in contact with the bed. It was possible to print these directly on the bed with no raft and I printed at 50mm/s maximum to ensure the corners were as accurate as possible.

comments.text: Tried ABS, but they got soft @110c bed temp overtime. Printed these in PC-ABS and now it's not an issue. These do work great. Did you use a particular thread for these?
comments.author: Deifox

comments.text: Perfection.   Thank you Omegatron
comments.author: edhewson

comments.text: Best corner brackets I have ever used. I have done at least 100 prints without my glass shifting and no adjustment to them since first installed. Thanks for the great brackets!
comments.author: Bionicjayton

comments.text: I was looking at the rear corner pieces and the bolt seems to be off a fair amount.  I may try to just drill a new one but when I put it on the bed it has a gap between each side and the bed.  Is this intentional or larger glass?  Do you normally use the screw setup on all four corners?  Just wondering.
comments.author: wirlybird

comments.text: I find having the screw setup on just 2 corners works well - it holds in place and also allows plenty of adjustment for different sized glass plates
comments.author: wirlybird

comments.text:
Maybe you misunderstood me! The blank corner pieces have the hole drilled so the edges of the corner piece are no way near the bed. There is about a 4 mm gap on each side. The hole needs to move more toward the middle of the piece where now it is right out on the tip (corner point). Easy enough to drill a new hole.
Right now I am using some of my solid pieces that account for differences in glass size vs. bed size and it is still tricky to get the thing aligned ok!. In one dimension the glass is larger than the bed and in the other it is a little smaller. I was thinking to try the adjustable setup on all four corners and see what happens.
comments.author: omegatron

comments.text: Would you mind either making an adjustment or sharing a design file? my glass is 3mm thick so I either need to modify the design to have a slightly shorter top lip so the glass bed is the same height as the bracket or I need to print a shim which I can do but I feel like modifying the design for 3mm glass vs the standard 5mm glass is the best long term solution. excellent design though I love it!!!
comments.author: mikejsmith1985

comments.text: I went ahead and made some brackets based on the measurements of my bed and glass and its working beautifully! Thanks again!
comments.author: mikejsmith1985

comments.text: So I've been having trouble finding an answer to this question and I've been holding off buying a glass bed until I can get it. I'm hoping you can help since I'm planning to print this design to hold the bed. Question: Can you still use these when using a heated bed? I do all of my prints with the bed heated and I can see how this could be an issue. I never heat above 105ºC and I assume this item needs to be printed with ABS for exactly this reason, but still, it's right against the heat. Would it be ok?
comments.author: Jack_Dark

comments.text: My prints run at maximum bed temp of 110ºC so that's the highest I can vouch for but yes that's the reason I recommend printing in ABS and I've been using mine for about 8 months without having to replace.
comments.author: Jack_Dark

comments.text: Thanks! I'll get them printed today.
comments.author: omegatron

comments.text: This doesn't make sense to me.  If I put the screw part on and tighten the bed bolt then the corner piece wont slide on.  It hits the bed.  If I leave the screw piece loose, slide on the corner piece then tighten down the bed bolt it pinches the corner piece so it doesn't move.  If I leave the bed bolt loose enough so the corner piece will move then everything is loose.
comments.author: wirlybird

comments.text: You slide the corner piece on and then tighten the vertical screw+nut using an allen key from the top.
comments.author: wirlybird

comments.text:
The problem is that the heating element is not tight to the bed on the corners in this case. In order to move the corner piece I have to leave the bolt loose or it might as well be a stationary corner.
Thanks for the reply and nice design but not working for me
comments.author: omegatron

comments.text: You could possibly add an additional nut after the original nut that holds the bed corners. This would push the corner pieces down a little but there should be enough height in them they would still work as intended - or could be slightly extended to service this requirement.
comments.author: wirlybird

comments.text:
I'll take a look at that, it gives me an idea. I think if I can space the screw part down enough so it can be tight but not completely pinch the corner piece I could eliminate the looseness. The problem I was running into is that vibration from certain prints is causing just enough for the corners to loosen slightly and allow a small shift in the glass plate.
Thanks for the info.
For the time I went ahead and built my own corner brackets but I do like this concept and will explore some more.
comments.author: omegatron

comments.text: For the blank corners, the screw hole and corner don't match up it seems. With a screw in, the corner sits a few millimeters away from the corner of the bed.
comments.author: bloodmoneyXIII

comments.text: It was intended to be a fixed one so you would just adjust at one place instead - IE print out one fixed and one adjustable to work together - I just wanted to give some wiggle room so it wouldn't hit anyones bed. :-)
comments.author: bloodmoneyXIII

comments.text: Do you use a glass bed that's larger than the build plate? If I used a fixed corner and an adjust able corner on the opposite side, the adjustable corner will bottom out and the glass plate will not be secure.
comments.author: omegatron

comments.text: What are the dimensions of your glass bed? I've gotten a few from Flashforge that varied by a 1mm or so and so I'll need to make minute adjustments to make my beds fit snugly.
comments.author: coreygeorge

comments.text:
I just made this. It seems it'll work pretty well. I like that it clamps the glass horizontally and is below the glass surface. The only thing I'm not a big fan of is that it utilizes the existing nuts underneath the heating plate in a way that you can't tighten them down fully. Because there is a hexagonal inset in the printed screw and the screw needs to come out diagonally from the build plate, you can't fully tighten the metal nut down onto the printed screw.
Some advice for printing: you only need supports for the corner piece. I wouldn't use the one with the tapered bottom, the squared one works fine. I printed 4 sets: one for each corner. A drop of 3-in-1 oil helps the screw. we'll see how it holds up to the heat over time.
comments.author: koreywithak

comments.text: Thanks for the constructive comments! The one with the tapered bottom was the original piece and I also find it's easier to go with the squared so I think I'll end up just removing it. A 5mm~ shim would probably go nicely as well right?! I'll get onto this when I have some spare time.
comments.author: koreywithak

comments.text: Well I feel stupid. Yes, I hadn't taken off the surface covering yet and I can see the tops of the screws (which I assumed were embedded). Therefore, the screws can be tightened just as you describe. It would be helpful to have pictures of the top and bottom of that screw as well as have some limited installation instructions. I'll upload some of my own when I get to it. Thanks for your design!
comments.author: omegatron

comments.text: Is this designed for 1/4" glass?
comments.author: sygyzy

comments.text: As long as the glass is thicker than 3.5 mm, it should work since it clamps from the sides. Make sure you print a proper z-stop adjustment piece.
comments.author: sygyzy

comments.text:
Great work. The glass cutter at Lowes was unable to cut a 6"x9" piece of glas, was off by 1/4-1/8th and this did the trick.
Thanks.
comments.author: MacPilot

comments.text: Glad to hear it! :-)
comments.author: MacPilot

comments.text: 180 degree flip with 30% infill and supports did it for me. Thanks for the design. Now my prints stay still and my wings nuts do not come loose. Perfect
comments.author: nxtastro

comments.text: No Matter what i do i cant get this to print. The extruder tip grabs the print once it prints supports material and pulls up the print. Im not sure what the purpose of the curve on the bottom is but it would be much easier to print with out it
comments.author: nxtastro

comments.text: They were part of the original design I remixed but I've just uploaded a squared off version that's easier to print.

title: Ducati Data Analyzer (DDA) Dongle "case" / keychain adapter

description.text: The Ducati Data Analyzer (DDA) storage dongle  is comprised of two separate pieces: the dongle itself, and the USB connector cap. This thing serves several functions. First, it keeps the cap and the dongle together. Second, it protects the connector on the side of the dongle that interfaces with the bike. Finally, it provides a way for the dongle to be attached to a keychain.
Print then snap your DDA dongle in the case and attach a keyring. I use an "S-Biner" to make attaching and detaching easy.

author: Niglew

description.text: The best idea of Netherlands! Very simple design that can be used to store your UM original power supply underneath your Ultimaker. The good thing about this design is that you don't need to drill holes in the casing of the Ultimaker. And that's good because we don't want to drill holes in our beautiful Ultimaker! It just snap fits on existing holes :) I found that it was really important that this model can be print within an hour, with as less material as possible. I made this design during my internship at FABLAB. And made it in Tinkercad. The model is in the Tinkercad library ( https://tinkercad.com/things/lUDndXUSWLA ) as well, so feel free to adjust the design to your own preferences.
